citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
* A female, grey and white, Chinese Crested dog (ID number 933000320376107) was constantly squinting its’ right eye.
The eye had a greenish discharge that the licensee wiped away prior to photo/video documentation. The center part of
eye was blueish and hazy. Closer examination revealed some reddish crusty material in the hair around the right eye The
white of the eye is mildly reddened. There was excessive discharge from eye causing the hair around the eye to be wet. I
asked the licensee when the last time the eye was treat. The licensee stated, that their veterinary tech. treated the eye
two to four weeks ago. The licensee stated, the Attending Veterinarian saw this dog and had documentation. However,
there was no documentation provided upon request. The licensee mentioned, this dog eye gets infected every time she
cycles because of her hormones. Conditions of the eyes can be due to infections, allergies, injury, irritation, or other
medical conditions that could be painful.
Due to the ongoing condition of the right eye, the licensee must have this dog evaluated by a veterinarian for veterinary
care and appropriate treatment plan. The outcome of this consultation must be documented and provided to the inspector
upon request. The licensee must ensure that all animals always receive adequate veterinary care.
To be corrected by 19-June-2023.

* The end enclosure on the west side of the Main Kennel building has paneling along the bottom of where the front
paneling and ground meet. This paneling is used to prevent the four adult Pomeranians from digging out. This panel has
approximately 1-inch-long protruding points where it was cut. These protruding points were sharp when touched and were
somewhat slanted upward into the enclosure. These points could be easily accessed by the dogs from their head to feet
thus, possibly causing injury the dogs.
For the prevention of injury to the dogs, all enclosures must be free of sharp edges and protruding sharp points.
To be corrected by, 20-June-2023.

* Several enclosures in the whelping building housing a total of 32 puppies had plastic slated flooring with openings. The
puppy’s feet passed through the openings in the plastic flooring when walking/running across this flooring in a normal
range of motion. One enclosure, the four puppies were reluctant to move off a 12-inch by 12-inch grey plastic mat. This is
due to their feet passing through the openings in the slated plastic flooring. Flooring that allows the feet of the dogs to
pass through can affect the animals' gait and or cause injury with a foot getting stuck in the opening.
For the prevention of injury, development of abnormal gait and the health and well-being of the puppies, all enclosures
with flooring that has openings must not allow the dogs’ feet to pass through the openings.
To be corrected by, 20-June-2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
* A female, grey and white, Chinese Crested dog (ID number 933000320376107) was constantly squinting its’ right eye. 
The eye had a greenish discharge that the licensee wiped away prior to photo/video documentation. The center part of 
eye was blueish and hazy. Closer examination revealed some reddish crusty material in the hair around the right eye The 
white of the eye is mildly reddened. There was excessive discharge from eye causing the hair around the eye to be wet. I 
asked the licensee when the last time the eye was treat. The licensee stated, that their veterinary tech. treated the eye 
two to four weeks ago. The licensee stated, the Attending Veterinarian saw this dog and had documentation. However, 
there was no documentation provided upon request. The licensee mentioned, this dog eye gets infected every time she 
cycles because of her hormones. Conditions of the eyes can be due to infections, allergies, injury, irritation, or other 
medical conditions that could be painful.  
 
Due to the ongoing condition of the right eye, the licensee must have this dog evaluated by a veterinarian for veterinary 
care and appropriate treatment plan. The outcome of this consultation must be documented and provided to the inspector 
upon request. The licensee must ensure that all animals always receive adequate veterinary care. 
 
To be corrected by 19-June-2023. 
3.6(a)(2)(i) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
* The end enclosure on the west side of the Main Kennel building has paneling along the bottom of where the front 
paneling and ground meet. This paneling is used to prevent the four adult Pomeranians from digging out. This panel has 
approximately 1-inch-long protruding points where it was cut. These protruding points were sharp when touched and were 
somewhat slanted upward into the enclosure. These points could be easily accessed by the dogs from their head to feet 
thus, possibly causing injury the dogs.  
 
For the prevention of injury to the dogs, all enclosures must be free of sharp edges and protruding sharp points.  
 
To be corrected by, 20-June-2023. 
3.6(a)(2)(x)  Direct

Primary enclosures. 
* Several enclosures in the whelping building housing a total of 32 puppies had plastic slated flooring with openings. The 
puppy’s feet passed through the openings in the plastic flooring when walking/running across this flooring in a normal 
range of motion. One enclosure, the four puppies were reluctant to move off a 12-inch by 12-inch grey plastic mat. This is 
due to their feet passing through the openings in the slated plastic flooring. Flooring that allows the feet of the dogs to 
pass through can affect the animals' gait and or cause injury with a foot getting stuck in the opening.  
 
For the prevention of injury, development of abnormal gait and the health and well-being of the puppies, all enclosures 
with flooring that has openings must not allow the dogs’ feet to pass through the openings.  
 
To be corrected by, 20-June-2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the facility representative.
